image.altText: Two firefigthers at truck

items.synopsis: After two days of cooler temperatures, firefighters in south-western Queensland are on high alert today, with hot weather and strong winds expected to make for dangerous fire conditions. Follow live.

title.children: More than 50 homes lost as Queensland braces for 'extremely savage day'

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: We were hearing overnight that 46 homes had been lost, but that has now been updated to 53, Western Downs Mayor Paul McVeigh confirmed on ABC News. "So very, very tough situation and we haven't ascertained all the damage as yet. Some of the areas the just too hot to get into. We are expecting that those numbers will increase and which is a really savage blow to the owners of those residents and certainly to our community. "Can I say a very big thank you to our whole community, how our community has rallied behind and in support of those who have been victims of this fire, it's been incredible. "And hopefully some of the meetings we're having today, we're out in Tara to try to support our community, let them know where some of that support can come from as well."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Savage' news that 53 homes have been lost on the Western Downs

children.content: We were hearing overnight that 46 homes had been lost, but that has now been updated to 53,
Western Downs Mayor Paul McVeigh
confirmed on ABC News.

"So very, very tough situation and we haven't ascertained all the damage as yet. Some of the areas the just too hot to get into. We are expecting that those numbers will increase and which is a really savage blow to the owners of those residents and certainly to our community.
"Can I say a very big thank you to our whole community, how our community has rallied behind and in support of those who have been victims of this fire, it's been incredible.
"And hopefully some of the meetings we're having today, we're out in Tara to try to support our community, let them know where some of that support can come from as well."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Residents of properties between Wieambilla Road, Chinchilla Tara Road, Upper Humbug Road, Drildool Road, Joseph Street and Clynes/Weitzels Road have been told to LEAVE IMMEDIATELY. QFES says: "There are multiple dangerous fires burning in the area." "QFES has used Emergency Alert text and voice message to warn people in the affected area about this fire."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Emergency warning: Tara, Montrose North, Wieambilla and The Gums

children.content: Residents of properties between Wieambilla Road, Chinchilla Tara Road, Upper Humbug Road, Drildool Road, Joseph Street and Clynes/Weitzels Road have been told to
LEAVE IMMEDIATELY
QFES says: "There are multiple dangerous fires burning in the area."
"QFES has used Emergency Alert text and voice message to warn people in the affected area about this fire."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A large air tanker has been brought closer to the firegrounds, as firefighters predict extra pressure on containment lines in southern Queensland today. Deputy Commissioner Joanne Greenfield said the tanker had been moved from Bundaberg to Wellcamp, near Toowoomba, to be near the at-risk areas. Extreme fire danger has been declared for the Darling Downs and Granite Belt today. "That means that when fire gets on the ground, it will be quite hard to control," Deputy Commissioner Greenfield said at a press conference yesterday.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Extreme fire danger for Darling Downs, Granite Belt

children.content: A large air tanker has been brought closer to the firegrounds, as firefighters predict extra pressure on containment lines in southern Queensland today.
Deputy Commissioner Joanne Greenfield said the tanker had been moved from Bundaberg to Wellcamp, near Toowoomba, to be near the at-risk areas.
Extreme fire danger has been declared for the Darling Downs and Granite Belt today.
"That means that when fire gets on the ground, it will be quite hard to control," Deputy Commissioner Greenfield said at a press conference yesterday.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Like Looney Tunes' famous cartoon villain, the Reserve Bank risks running Australia's economy over a cliff if it becomes too single-minded in its pursuit of the inflation Road Runner, writes Michael Janda.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Is Australia's economy facing a Wile E Coyote moment?

featuredLink.title: The Reserve Bank is trying to hammer inflation, but will it break the economy doing it?

children.content: Like Looney Tunes' famous cartoon villain, the Reserve Bank risks running Australia's economy over a cliff if it becomes too single-minded in its pursuit of the inflation Road Runner, writes Michael Janda.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Rental listings in Hobart are at their highest level in a decade, while nationally availability has hit a record low. The price of rentals has also dropped by 7.4 per cent, compared with a 14.6 per cent rise nationally. Despite the changes to Hobart's market, housing advocates say the city remains unaffordable for many. Read more from Clancy Balen.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Hobart rental market bucks national trend

featuredLink.title: Hobart rental listings are at the highest level in a decade, as the city bucks the national trend

children.content: Rental listings in Hobart are at their highest level in a decade, while nationally availability has hit a record low.
The price of rentals has also dropped by 7.4 per cent, compared with a 14.6 per cent rise nationally.
Despite the changes to Hobart's market, housing advocates say the city remains unaffordable for many.
Read more from
Clancy Balen.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Wall Street rallied on Monday, kicking off what promises to be a hectic week that includes a heavy earnings docket, economic data and the Federal Reserve's two-day monetary policy meeting. All three major US stock indexes closed up more than 1 per cent, bouncing back from the previous week's sell-off. Interest-rate-sensitive megacap stocks, led by Microsoft, Amazon, and Apple provided the most upside muscle. "Today is an earnings rebound," said Oliver Pursche, senior vice president at Wealthspire Advisors, in New York. "The market got oversold, and the reality is that earnings have been pretty good, the US economy continues to chug along, and is likely to do so in the fourth quarter and into the first part of next year." Third-quarter earnings season, firing on all cylinders, has reached its halfway point, with 251 of the companies in the S & P 500 having reported. Of those, 78 per cent have beaten Wall Street estimates, according to LSEG. Analysts now expect, on aggregate, annual third-quarter S & P 500 earnings growth of 4.3 per cent, a marked improvement over the 1.6 per cent year-on-year growth seen at the beginning of October. Investors have shown "less pessimism," Pursche added. "First- and second-quarter calls had a more negative tone. There was anxiety over interest rates, Fed policy, the recession that never came." In the coming week, Caterpillar, Apple, Pfizer and Starbucks are among the higher-profile companies expected to post results. On Tuesday, the Federal Open Markets Committee is expected to convene for a two-day monetary policy meeting, which is expected to culminate in a decision to let the Fed funds target rate stand at 5.25-5.50 per cent. Investors will scrutinize the accompanying statement and Fed chair Jerome Powell's subsequent Q & A session for clues regarding the central bank's path forward with rates. "The Fed wants to see the cumulative effects of their rate hikes on the economy but they've also said they're prepared to over-shoot in an abundance of caution, as long as inflation is above 3 per cent," Pursche said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Wall Street bounces, powered by earnings momentum

children.content: Wall Street rallied on Monday, kicking off what promises to be a hectic week that includes a heavy earnings docket, economic data and the Federal Reserve's two-day monetary policy meeting.
All three major US stock indexes closed up more than 1 per cent, bouncing back from the previous
week's sell-off.
Interest-rate-sensitive megacap
stocks, led by Microsoft, Amazon, and Apple provided the most upside muscle.

"Today is an earnings rebound," said Oliver Pursche, senior vice president at Wealthspire Advisors, in New York. "The market got oversold, and the reality is that earnings have been pretty good, the US economy continues to chug along, and is likely to do so in the fourth quarter and into the first part of next year."
Third-quarter earnings season, firing on all cylinders, has reached its halfway point, with 251 of the companies in the S
P 500 having reported. Of those, 78 per cent have beaten Wall Street estimates, according to LSEG.
Analysts now expect, on aggregate, annual third-quarter S
P 500 earnings growth of 4.3 per cent, a marked improvement over the 1.6 per cent year-on-year growth seen at the beginning of October.
Investors have shown "less pessimism," Pursche added. "First- and second-quarter calls had a more negative tone. There was anxiety over interest rates, Fed policy, the recession that never came."
In the coming week, Caterpillar, Apple, Pfizer and Starbucks are among the higher-profile companies expected to post results.

On Tuesday, the Federal Open Markets Committee is expected to convene for a two-day monetary policy meeting, which is expected to culminate in a decision to let the Fed funds target rate stand at 5.25-5.50 per cent.
Investors will scrutinize the accompanying statement and Fed chair Jerome Powell's subsequent Q
A session for clues regarding the central bank's path forward with rates.

"The Fed wants to see the cumulative effects of their rate hikes on the economy but they've also said they're prepared to over-shoot in an abundance of caution, as long as inflation is above 3 per cent," Pursche said.
